data.text:
Robert Silverberg's collection of the "best" sci-fi stories written from the 20's to the 60's is one of my all time favorite books, as so many of the stories are so powerful that they just stay with you...forever. Nightfall, Microcosmic God, Flowers for Algeron, on and on. To say that these stories have been influention in shaping sci-fi is also an understatement.

I have been considerably less impressed with the "best of" particular year books that are still published, and really havent ever come across anything like Silberberg's book. Anyone know of anything else that really impressed you?

My favorite anthology was Space Odyssey:An Anthology of Great Science Fiction Stories. I got it in 1990, but I think it first came out in GB in 1983. It had stories by Silverberg, Vonnegut Jr, Clarke, Pohl... Its hard to remember exactly what I was thinking 20 years ago at age 15, but I'm pretty sure this book started my obsession with science fiction.

I have read a few newer ones and nothing in them really impressed me. The latest was Infinities: The Best of British SF. Ive tried to start almost every story in it and lost interest in all of them early on.

But like the OP if anyone has any good recommendations Id love to give them a try

A couple of older ones I'd further recommend, though they are getting hard to get and especially so here in the UK. I had to order them secondhand from the States:

The Astounding Science Fiction Anthology edited by John W Campbell; A Treasury of Science Fiction and The Big Book of Science Fiction, edited by Groff Conklin and Adventures in Space and Time edited by Raymond J. Healy and J. Francis McComas (Link for details)

Someone here recommended Isaac Asimov's Treasury of Science Fiction a while back (sorry can't remember who, exactly!) and I would wholeheartedly recommend it also. A nice big book and cheap. The contents include:

VOLUME ONE: THE FUTURE IN QUESTION

Why? by Robert Silverberg

What's become of Screwloose? by Ron Goulart

Houston, Houston, Do you read? by James Tiptree, Jr.

Where have you been Billy boy, Billy boy? by Kate Wilhelm

If all men were brothers, would you let one marry your sister? by Theodore Sturgeon

Will you Wait? by Alfred Bester

Who goes there? by John W. Campbell, Jr.

An eye for what? by Damon Knight

I Plinglot, who you? by Frederik Pohl

Will you walk a little faster? by William Tenn

Who's in charge here? by James Blish

The Last Question, by Isaac Asimov

VOLUME TWO: SPACE MAIL

Introduction by Isaac Asimov

LETTERS

I never ast no favors, by C.M Kornbluth

Letter to Ellen, by Chan Davis

One rejection too many, by Patricia Nurse

Space opera, by Ray Russell

The invasion of the terrible Titans, by William Sambrot

That only a Mother, by Judith Merril

Itch on the Bull Run, by Sharon Webb

Letter to a Phoenix, by Fredric Brown

Who's Cribbing? by Jack Lewis

Computers don't argue, by Godron R. Dickson

Letters from Laura, by Mildred Clingerman

Dear Pen Pal, by A.E van Vogt

Damn shame, by Dean R. Lambe

The trap, by Howard Fast

DIARIES

Flowers for Algernon, by Daniel Keyes

The second kind of loneliness, by George R. R. Martin

MEMOS

The Lonely, by Judith Merril

Secret Unattainable, by A.E van Vogt

After the Great Space War, by Barry N. Malzberg

The Prisoner, by Christopher Anvil

Request for proposal, by Anthony R. Lewis

He walked around the horse, by H. Beam Piper

The Power, by Murray Leinster.

Mark

Just to point out, the Silverberg "best," by which I think you mean the SF Hall of Fame anthologies, were stories voted on by the SF Writers of America (real association name may vary from remembered assn. name). Those folks had multiple years of perspective that a "year's best" anthologist doesn't have -- most of the stories they voted in were between 20 and 40 years old at the time, and most of them had been discussed and argued over since publication, anthologized numerous times already, were well-known within the field, and their position in the anthology was really already established and voting, if not quite a formality, was nearly so.

I've enjoyed Dangerous Visions, Adventures in Time and Space, and The Norton Book of Science Fiction (poking through it for years now, still haven't finished).

Randy M.
